title: Study Results: How well do harassment prevention interventions transfer between communities?

last_post.content:
In oral arguments, Supreme Court justices asked a question that we can answer with science: do policies against harassment cause a chilling effect on freedom of expression?

In multiple large-scale field experiments, we have found that policies that restrict harmful speech actually increase the free exercise of speech rights.

Here's our latest data: https://citizensandtech.org/2022/08/harassment-prevention-across-communities/

title: Evaluating Verifiability in Generative Search Engines

last_post.content:
Responses from existing generative search engines (Bing Chat, NeevaAI, this http URL, and YouChat) are fluent and appear informative, but frequently contain unsupported statements and inaccurate citations: 51% of generated sentences are fully supported by citations and only 74% of citations support their associated sentence

I have a new game! And it is out now:

Drift Mine Satellite is a maintenance text adventure about a person living underground in a limestone mine, and their work on the local communication network that has sprung up there.

It is a utopian apocalypse fantasy, a forever-camping world narrowed to linear miles of RVs parked under a mountain, the people who live in them, and the systems that interconnect them, both social and material.

Blog post: "Deploying key transparency at WhatsApp"

Key transparency has been a sort of holy grail of encrypted messaging systems which ensures that if the messaging system advertises a malicious public key for your user, there's a permanent record of it.

There have been several projects before this like CONIKS and Google's Key Transparency, but none of them shipped. Seeing it actually happen is exciting for me.

https://engineering.fb.com/2023/04/13/security/whatsapp-key-transparency/
@Brad_Rosenheim @binx There has been a lot of focused mapping efforts in the past few years adding to that total through the Seabed 2030 project. https://seabed2030.org/

title: University of Glasgow - Schools - School of Psychology & Neuroscience  - Research - Pedagogy and Education Research Unit (PERU)

last_post.content:
Very excited to share the new Pedagogy and Education Research Unit at UofG Psych Neuro. Our activities and research have a strong applied focus as well as being underpinned by a commitment to open science and open educational resources.

https://www.gla.ac.uk/schools/psychologyneuroscience/research/peru/

The unit consists of three themes: Access, Inclusion and Wellbeing led by Chiara Horlin, Applied Cognition in Learning and Teaching led by Carolina Kuepper-Tetzel, and Open Science and Pedagogy led by @HelenaPaterson

If you'd like to be added to the Team, let me know!

#pedagogy #education #scholarship #educationresearch

title: Oversight Board | Independent Judgment. Transparency. Legitimacy.

last_post.content:
This bit on misinformation label effectiveness in today’s Facebook Oversight Board opinion is fascinating.

Short version is: Facebook automatically spray neutral “get the facts” labels on both true and false content (which they did throughout the 2020 election, and always seemed like a bit of a milquetoast non-intervention). They found experimental evidence of label fatigue — that is, people are less engaged with labels when they see them too often.

Full opinion: https://www.oversightboard.com/decision/PAO-SABU4P2S/

Our #chi2023 paper considers how people who stutter access voice assistants — and, it does a rare thing!, it starts with a large-scale study with people who stutter (n=61), connects those results to a deep understanding of how speech systems work, and follows through with technical improvements that significantly improve performance (in several ways, including in the released “Siri Pause Time”) feature … this is the kind of work I came to industry to be part of.

https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~jbigham/pubs/pdfs/2023/stutter-speech.pdf

While R isn't my favorite language of the ones I regularly use, I know you #rstats people adore it, so here's a fun package you should try out:

https://github.com/dirkschumacher/transduceR

If you like functional style, but want efficiency too, try out transducers, they're an amazing little tool that I'm still picking up, but they give you pipelines that don't create intermediate arrays (and composable reductions, lazy evaluation in this case, etc). Thus, they still provide clean, familiar functional syntax but with a pretty sizable performance boost!

Here's a conceptual primer on them from Clojure as well:

https://clojure.org/reference/transducers

I hope this proves useful to some of you! 😁

title: Goodbye to Netflix DVDs, The Last Good Tech Company

last_post.content: “The demise of Netflix DVDs is about more than the loss of a great way to watch movies. It is about the passing of an era where the great big tech companies of the day thought the internet was a way to improve the offline life rather than to replace it.” https://www.vice.com/en/article/5d9be5/goodbye-to-netflix-dvds-the-last-good-tech-company?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email

Judith Love Cohen was the engineer who made Apollo's Abort Guidance System, which was crucial to saving the ill-fated Apollo 13. She finished it while in labor, then (the same day) delivered her younger son -- the actor Jack Black.

This is one of those utterly remarkable #space stories that I stumble over once in a while and it blows my mind afresh every single time.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judith_Love_Cohen

Competition is just a click (and $45b) away
https://www.justice.gov/opa/press-release/file/1328941/download

> #Google pays $45 billion a year for contracts to lock out rivals, signing deals with “Apple, LG, Motorola, and Samsung; major U.S. wireless carriers such as AT&T, T-Mobile, and Verizon; and browser developers such as Mozilla, Opera, and UCWeb— to secure default status for its general search engine and, in many cases, to specifically prohibit Google’s counterparties from dealing with Google’s competitors.”

title: Right to Read Day | Unite Against Book Bans

last_post.content:
Great to see the American Library Association directly contesting the current wave of book banning censorship.

Again, this is the kind of "crime" that institutionalized invasion of privacy -- whether it be online age verification laws or client side scanning -- will be used to detect and prosecute. We need to connect these things quickly, and repeatedly, as we push back.

https://uniteagainstbookbans.org/right-to-read-day/

Love the work @evan has been putting in. Was just reading through the new #ActivityStreams extensions primer and kept thinking "I didn't know you could do that!" while going over examples. https://www.w3.org/wiki/Activity_Streams/Primer/Extensions

title: A new group in Maine would reorganize the Portland Press Herald as a nonprofit

last_post.content: A new organization in Maine seeks to raise $15 million to buy the Portland Press Herald and its sister papers — and convert them all to nonprofits. My Media Nation post: #LocalNews https://dankennedy.net/2023/04/23/a-new-organization-in-maine-would-reorganize-the-portland-press-herald-as-a-nonprofit/
